newsitem.title: GERMANY: German officials fear floods may burst river banks.
newsitem.headline: German officials fear floods may burst river banks.

text.p: German officials said on Saturday they feared dykes may not stand up to the strain of a wave of floods which has already claimed scores lives in neighbouring Poland.
Alwin Ziel, the interior minister in the state of Brandenburg, said the floods could last up to 14 days, putting the banks and flood walls under severe pressure.
The floods have left areas close to the Oder river bodering Germany and Poland under water.
Werner Mueller, a senior regional government official coordinating efforts to minimise flood damage, said the flood walls had held up to the strain so far.

"What worries us, however, is that if the rain increases and lasts for a longer period then that could combine with the water which has been lying on the dykes for a long time to weaken the dykes," Mueller said. "That's our greatest fear."
Floods in Poland have killed almost 50 people, swamped 4,000 sq km and hit a thousand villages and population centres such as the major cities of Wroclaw and Opole.

German Police have already closed off bridges over the Oder to Poland and have evacuated small numbers of people from their homes. But fears the water would reach a level overnight threatening large parts of Frankfurt proved unfounded.
